claims.quote: Labor is offering households up to $2,200 to purchase solar panels
eventually taking the total number of NSW homes with rooftop solar past the one-million mark.
Eligible homes must be owner-occupied
the scheme is restricted to families on a combined income of no more than $180,000 per year.
The move will help ease the pressure on New South Wales’ ageing and unreliable coal-fired generators,
while also lowering pollution and power prices.
the scheme would save families up to $1000 a year.
The Liberals responded the following next day,
announcing a policy to offer interest-free loans to families to install rooftop solar and battery storage systems.
The Liberal plan will cover 300,000 homes,
be capped at a combined household income of $180,000.
Labor’s policy is a strong start
offering grants rather than loans
there is still room for improvement
the need to include renters in their plans.
Gladys Berejiklian’s Liberals need to do more.
8 years of climate inaction from the NSW Liberals
There are already commercial operators offering low or no-interest loans for solar installation,
all the parties are at least recognising the need to increase solar uptake
the Greens have an even more ambitious policy than both their major rivals
a bold plan to make solar and battery storage mandatory at all new homes in New South Wales.
The scheme would also see all NSW government buildings powered by 100 percent renewable energy.
All proposals will help reduce the pressure on New South Wales’ ageing and unreliable coal fleet
help families deal with high power prices.
none of the policies do enough to offer clean energy solutions to people unable to access solar, like apartment dwellers.
People who rent deserve to be able to access clean and cheap energy too.

Greenpeace is calling on the next New South Wales government to introduce a solar rebate to help families that are renting, to access solar panels – or help those who already have
      solar to install battery storage.
it’s debatable that this policy adds much value without a suite of other targeted measures.
this policy is too little, too late.

warrant.text: Because similar commercial loans already exist, a government loan policy may add limited additional value without complementary measures.
Given the policy follows eight years of inaction, it can reasonably be judged insufficient.
If a policy is too little and too late, more action is needed from its proponents.
Identifying a specific unmet need exemplifies that improvement is still required.
Since current policies do not serve renters and renters deserve access to clean, cheap energy, a targeted rebate is warranted.
If a scheme saves families up to $1000 a year, it helps them cope with high power prices.

conclusions.quote:
Greenpeace is calling on the next New South Wales government to introduce a solar rebate to help families that are renting, to access solar panels – or help those who already have
      solar to install battery storage.
it’s debatable that this policy adds much value without a suite of other targeted measures.
this policy is too little, too late.

claims.quote: current circumstances have made it quite obvious to me that I can not afford to wait until then to make a difference in the global battle against climate change.
I must start now.
This is exactly what I have done.
I have been a climate activist for roughly three years now.
my class was shown the environmental documentary ‘Before The Flood’ by Leonardo Di Caprio.
a man as busy as Di Caprio took the time to film a documentary aimed to raise awareness for climate change
it must be an important issue.
I started to spend hours researching about climate change
prior to the documentary, I had no idea that climate change was even a thing.
were in a global existential crisis.
all the alarming statistics and data put fear right into my heart
past generations, the main contributors of climate change, were not willing to make up for their mistakes and save my future.
I didn’t want others to suffer from this crisis
it motivated me to take my future into my own hands and encourage other young people to do the same.

warrant.text: If one cannot afford to wait to make a difference, then one should begin acting immediately.
A global existential crisis combined with unwillingness of main contributors to act makes delaying efforts untenable.
The text uses an if–then: if a busy Di Caprio made a climate-awareness documentary, then the issue is important; since he did, the conclusion follows.
Recognizing an issue as important can motivate sustained personal research into it.
The author explicitly cites lack of prior knowledge as a reason for beginning extensive research (‘as …’).
The author states that fear coupled with not wanting others to suffer motivated taking action.

conclusions.quote: it motivated me to take my future into my own hands and encourage other young people to do the same.

claims.quote: Ms Stephan calls Schellnhuber’s type of climate activism an attempt at creating an “above the law state of emergency”
The new religion promises the Last Judgement already today
we endeavour one last huge and dramatic effort to save humanity from a well-deserved downfall.
As is the case with other religions, the best is repentance, humility and self-restriction – preferably through emission payments without end.
Stephan writes that the new climate religion fills a void left behind by other religions, and tells us to feel guilty about prosperity.

we’ll have to pay the price for our prosperity – be it to God or Nature, – with Biblical plagues such as storms, huge tidal waves, floods, fire-spewing volcanoes, in short: death
  and demons
Stephan warns us not to doubt the elite prophets who have the powers, tools and instruments to see deep into the future
The new priests who proclaim these scenarios have attracted billions of followers with their announcements of world downfall.
they do not tolerate any doubts about their predictions.
Those who dare express doubt are nothing more than egotistical wretches, appeasers and trivializers, block-headed deniers or worse, or to the least paid agents of evil.
the climate zealotry and hysteria spread though society
the obstacles that prevent necessary action, like democracy, be removed and replaced globally by an “authoritarian regime of experts”
projected global downfall is the state-of-emergency that justifies every measure and it distracts us from every other unfinished business.

warrant.text: The text states that because zealotry and hysteria are spreading, it is logical that obstacles to action be removed.
Creating an “above the law state of emergency” implies overriding democratic constraints in favor of expert rule.
A movement with billions of followers can enable or demand structural political changes such as replacing democracy with expert rule.
Intolerance of doubt is characteristic of authoritarian approaches that remove democratic obstacles.
Stigmatizing dissenters as morally corrupt supports sidelining democratic deliberation in favor of imposed rule.
Labeling the activism as an attempt at an above-the-law emergency aligns with a state of emergency that justifies every measure and distracts from other issues.
Apocalyptic promises, prescribed repentance, and deference to prophetic experts together frame a perpetual emergency that justifies any measure and sidelines other priorities.

conclusions.quote: the obstacles that prevent necessary action, like democracy, be removed and replaced globally by an “authoritarian regime of experts”
projected global downfall is the state-of-emergency that justifies every measure and it distracts us from every other unfinished business.

claims.quote: The issue of challenges to the IPCC consensus statement on attribution is not analogous to Galileo-like revolutionaries.
Rather these challenges are associated with a concern about the oversimplification by the IPCC of a complex issue in the interests of policy making.
How to reason about uncertainties in the complex climate system and its computer simulations is neither simple nor obvious.

Scientific debates involve controversies over the value and importance of particular classes of evidence as well as disagreement about the appropriate logical framework for linking and assessing the evidence.

The IPCC faces a daunting challenge with regards to characterizing and reasoning about uncertainty, assessing the quality of evidence, linking the evidence into arguments, identifying areas of ignorance and assessing confidence levels.
An overarching concern is how the issue of climate change is framed scientifically and how judgments about confidence in complex scientific arguments are made in view of the cascade of uncertainties.
Given the complexity of the climate problem, ‘expert judgments’ about uncertainty and confidence levels are made by the IPCC on issues that are dominated by unquantifiable uncertainties.
It is difficult to avoid concluding that the IPCC consensus is manufactured and that the existence of this consensus does not lend intellectual substance to their conclusions.

claims_extra.canonical: Reasoning about climate uncertainty and evidential linking is complex and contested

warrant.text: If uncertainties are complex and debates disagree over evidence and logic, then reasoning about the issue is complex and contested.
If a complex, contested issue is oversimplified for policy, the resulting consensus is constructed rather than organically emergent.
If conclusions rest on expert judgments under unquantifiable uncertainties amid acknowledged difficulty, the consensus reflects judgment calls rather than settled knowledge.
An explicit statement that it is difficult to avoid concluding the consensus is manufactured supports that conclusion.
If reasoning is complex and the institution faces a daunting uncertainty task, mere consensus does not add intellectual substance to conclusions.
If challenges are not mere Galileo-style crankery, then the existence of consensus alone does not confer intellectual weight on the conclusions.
Where judgments are dominated by unquantifiable uncertainties, consensus signals agreement not additional evidential substance.

conclusions.canonical: The existence of the IPCC consensus does not lend intellectual substance to the IPCC’s conclusions
